div.l: Lo such it is a Millere to be fals
And therfore this Prouerbe is seide ful soth
Hym dar nat wene wel that euil doth
A guilour shal him self beguiled be
And god that sit high in mageste
Saue al this company gret and smale
Thus haue I quit the Millere in my tale

hi.hi:
iere beginneth the Prolog
of the Cook of London̄ .

div.l:
The cook of London
whil the Reue spak ·

For ioye him thouȝt
he clawed him on the bak ·

A ha quod he
for cristes passion ·
This Millere had a sharp conclusion
Vpon his argument of herbergage
Wel said Salamon in his language
Ne bring nat eueri man in to thin hous
For herberwing be niȝt is perlous
Wel ouȝt a man avised for to be
Whom that he brouȝt in to his priuete
I pray to god so yeue me sorwe and care
If euer sith I hight Hogge of ware
Herde I a Millere better set awerke
He had a iape of malice in the derke
But god forbede that we stinten hiere
And therfore if ye vouchesaf to hiere
A tale of me that am a poore man
I wol you telle as wel as euer I can
A litil iape that fel in oure cite
Oure oost ansuerd and seid I graunt it the
Now telle on Roger and loke that it be good
For many a paste hast thou leten blood
